) Criminal seizure warrants are obtained from the court in the district where indictment will be sought or has been returned without regard to the the property subject to forfeiture or ordered forfeited. (
) If the asset to be seized is located on private property, a search warrant be obtained to legally enter the property and seize the asset. (

) Absent exigent circumstances, real property cannot be seized without its owner notice and opportunity for a pre-seizure hearing. When real is named in a forfeiture count or allegation, a notice of lis pendens should prepared by the US Attorney’s Office and filed with the local official who is sponsible for recording deeds. (

) A lis pendens is a notice that describes the real property and states that the United States has an interest in it as a result of the pending criminal The purpose of a lis pendens is to provide notice “to the world ” that who takes an interest in the property takes that interest subordinate to the interest of the United States. The effect of a lis pendens is to prevent a fide sale of the property or its refinancing pending the outcome of the forfeiture litigation. (

) State law governs when a lis pendens may be filed. Most states require a pending court action involving the property. In these jurisdictions, either a forfeiture complaint must be filed, or an indictment, information, or criminal complaint obtained listing the property as subject to forfeiture, in order to properly file a lis pendens. ) In order to criminally forfeit a defendant ’s property, the indictment or tion must contain a forfeiture count or allegation that alleges the extent of defendant ’s interest in the property. The primary purpose of this to put the defendant on notice that his/her property is subject to forfeiture. addition, the insertion of a forfeiture count or allegation in the indictment provides a basis for the issuance of pretrial restraining orders and criminal seizure warrants, puts third parties on notice that the government has an interest in the defendant’s assets that are subject to forfeiture, and may establish a factual basis for the forfeiture of the defendant’s assets in tion with a guilty plea. (

) An indictment may include an itemized list of the property to be forfeited, or general statement, which includes a list of each asset subject to forfeiture bill of particulars, that the government will seek to forfeit everything subject forfeiture under the applicable statute. (

(

) As soon as practicable after a defendant is found guilty by a jury or enters plea of guilty to any count in an indictment or information where criminal Order of ture is sought, the court will determine what property is subject to forfeiture. (

) If forfeiture of specific property is sought, the court, or upon the defendant’s request in a case in which a jury returns a verdict of guilty, the jury, will determine whether the government has established the required connection between the property and the offense committed by the defendant. If the ernment seeks a money judgment against the defendant, the court or the will determine the amount of money the defendant will be ordered to pay. (

) The court’s or the jury’s determination may be based on evidence already the record or, if the forfeiture is contested, on evidence or information presented by the parties at a hearing after the verdict or finding of guilt. (

) Once it is determined that property is subject to forfeiture, the court will promptly enter a preliminary order of forfeiture setting forth the amount of money judgment or directing the forfeiture of specific property. (
) The entry of a preliminary order of forfeiture authorizes the seizure of the specific property subject to forfeiture.
